title: InstructAgent: Building User Controllable Recommender via LLM Agent
author: Wujiang Xu (Rutgers University), Xuying Ning (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Xi Zhu (Rutgers University), Yunxiao Shi (University of Technology Sydney), Kai Mei (Rutgers University), Min Xu (University of Technology Sydney), Zujie Liang (Ant Group), Kun Wang (Nanyang Technological University), Yongfeng Zhang (Rutgers University)
relevance_why: The paper discusses a novel approach to recommendation systems using a user-agent collaboration that may inspire methods for enhancing personalization in audio-related AI systems.
background: The paper addresses the design of recommenders that allow users to exert more control through an instruction-aware agent, enhancing personalization and mitigating common biases in recommendations.
contribution: This paper introduces the Instruct2Agent to solve the limitations of traditional recommenders, achieving significant improvements in user satisfaction and personalization.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous systems mainly focused on platform-driven optimization and lacked mechanisms to truly accommodate individual user preferences, leading to echo chambers.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work implements an individual instruction-aware agent that learns from user-specific feedback and external knowledge, effectively promoting user autonomy.

key_innovation: The approach allows users to give flexible instructions, leading to more personalized and relevant recommendations while filtering out undesired content.
real_world_impact: The proposed system enhances the user experience in content consumption by adapting to individual preferences and helping avoid unwanted bias, which could have broad applications in various recommendation scenarios.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention limitations but may face challenges in real-world implementation involving diverse user preferences.

new_terms.instruction-aware agent: **Instruction-aware agent** is an intelligent system capable of understanding user instructions to provide tailored recommendations, enhancing user engagement and satisfaction.
new_terms.echo chamber effect: **Echo chamber effect** refers to situations where a user is only exposed to information that reinforces their existing beliefs, limiting diversity in content exposure.

open_sourcing: Datasets and code are publicly available at the URL provided in the paper.
